content.question: A student has a variable battery and two resistors, <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math>. Resistor <math alttext="X" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>X</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is ohmic, and the student wants to determine if <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> is ohmic. The student plans to connect all three components in a circuit and vary the <math alttext="e m f" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>e</mi><mi>m</mi><mi>f</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> provided by the battery. The potential difference across and current in resistor <math alttext="Y" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>Y</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> will be measured. How should the resistors be connected for the measurements to be useful?

choices.label: Either in series or in parallel
Neither in series nor in parallel

content.answer: Either in series or in parallel

skill.text: 3.B: Apply an appropriate law, definition, theoretical relationship, or model to make a claim.
